questions.text: Smallpox eradication was successful due to all of the following reasons except?

options.label: A
options.text: Subclinical cases did not transmit the disease

options.label: B
options.text: A highly effective vaccine was available

questions.correct_answer: D. Cross-resistance existed with animal pox
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cross-resistance existed with animal pox Eradication was successful of smallpox due to the - Subclinical cases did not transmit the disease A highly effective vaccine was available Infection provides lifelong immunity But not due to cross-resistance existence with animal pox; otherwise, it would not be eradicated.

questions.text: The infectivity of a person with centripetal pleomorphic rashes in the body lasts for?

options.label: B
options.text: 3 days after the onset of rashes

options.label: C
options.text: 5 days after the onset of rashes

options.label: D
options.text: Till the last scab falls off

questions.correct_answer: C. 5 days after the onset of rashes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 days after the onset of rashes From the given clinical picture, we can diagnose Chickenpox as characterized by centripetal, pleomorphic rashes that look like dew drops on rose petal appearance. The period of communicability of chicken pox is 2 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rashes. Hence the appropriate answer is option C.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and D – These are not the period of communicability of chicken pox.

questions.text: Infectivity of chickenpox lasts for

options.label: A
options.text: Till the last scab falls off

questions.correct_answer: B. 6 days after onset of rash
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6 days after onset of rash Chickenpox , also known as varicella the rash is infective till the onset of the development of a scab over the rash, which begins around 6 to 7 days after onset.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The chickenpox becomes noninfective before the scab falls off Option: C. Till 3 days after the onset of the rash, the rash stays infective Option: D. Fever has no connection with infectivity in chickenpox Other Period of Communicability-: Measles: 4 days before to 5 days after the appearance of the rash Chickenpox: one to two days before to 4- 5 days after the appearance of rash Diphtheria: 14-28 days from disease onset

questions.text: WHO declared that smallpox was globally eradicated on 8th May 1980. You are working as a medical officer in a peripheral PHC where you notice a child having vesicular rashes all over his trunk and limbs. How do you conclude as it is chickenpox infection but not smallpox:

options.label: A
options.text: As the rash involves palms and soles

options.label: B
options.text: As all the rashes are in the same stage

options.label: D
options.text: As the rash mainly involves the extensor aspect.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

As axilla is involved, Option: C. is correct because the chickenpox rash involves the axilla, while the axilla is usually spared in smallpox infection. Features of smallpox rash Deep-seated, firm, well-circumscribed vesicles later become umbilicated or confluent pustules. Start from face and forearm, then spreads to trunk Palms and soles - involved All in same stage Involves extensor aspect Axilla and mucosa not involved Slow healing - scab formation takes 10 - 14 days Features of Chickenpox rash Superficial vesicles - Dew drops on rose petals Centripetal distribution Pleomorphic Palms and soles - not involved Flexors, axilla, and mucosa - involved Rapid healing - scab formation takes 4 -7 days Option: A. B. and D. are characteristics of smallpox rash.

questions.text: A person with symmetrical centripetal rashes of pleomorphic stages was brought to the dermatology OPD. The concerned doctor in charge made a provisional diagnosis and started his treatment. He was advised by his department HOD to take vaccination against the same disease. What is the nature of the vaccine that he may take as a prophylactic measure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Live vaccine From the clinical picture, it can be diagnosed as Chickenpox caused by Varicella zoster. Now, we are using a live attenuated varicella virus vaccine. Hence, the correct option is Live vaccine – A

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Includes IPV, Hep B, etc. Option: C. Includes conjugate pneumococcal vaccine Option: D. Includes tetanus, diphtheria

questions.text: A child was vaccinated for measles 2 weeks back. But later, the child was presented with Koplik’s spots in the oral mucosa. Which will be the least common complication of this disease?

SSPE SSPE is the least common complication of measles.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Otitis media is the most common complication of Measles Option: C. Diarrhea is the second most complication of measles. Option: D. Pneumonia is the third most common complication of measles.

questions.text: In a family of 7 children, 2 are completely immunized. Suppose one of the children develops a cough, cold, and coryza with tiny white spots inside the buccal cavity. What will be the ideal duration of isolation period for the child to be followed to prevent the spread of the disease to other children too?

options.label: A
options.text: 4 days before and 4 days after the rash

options.label: B
options.text: 2 days before and 5 days after the rash

options.label: C
options.text: 7 days before and 7 days after the rash

options.label: D
options.text: 14-28 days from the onset of disease

questions.correct_answer: A. 4 days before and 4 days after the rash
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4 days before and 4 days after the rash The cough, cold, and coryza with koplik spot (pathognomic for Measles) suggest this is a case of MEASLES Transmission occurs directly from person to person mainly by droplet infection and droplet nuclei, from 4 days before the onset of rash until 4 days after that. DISEASE PERIOD OF COMMUNICABILITY Chicken pox 2 days before and 5 days after the rash Measles 4 days before and 5 days after the rash Mumps and Rubella 1 week before and 1 week after the rash Diphtheria 14 to 28 days after the onset of disease

questions.text: Which is the first site of the appearance of maculopapular rashes in measles?

Behind the ear The typical, dusky red, macular, or maculopapular rash begins behind the ear.

It is the site of the spread of typical maculopapular rashes from behind the ears within a few hours. Option: D. It is the last site of the spread of the typical macula-popular rashes in the measles.

questions.text: Which is the measles vaccination campaign 9 months – 15 years ago for elimination?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Catch up Catch up – Defined as a one-time, nationwide vaccination campaign targeting usually all children 9m-15 years of age regardless of history of measles disease or vaccination. Keep up – Defined as routine services aimed at vaccinating more than 95% of each successive birth cohort. Follow-up – Defined as a subsequent nationwide vaccination campaign conducted every 2-4 years, usually targeting children born after the catch-up campaign. Option C MOP UP is door-to-door immunizations carried out in endemic areas.

questions.text: A pregnant lady was infected with measles during her gestational age. What will be the outcome of this case scenario?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Premature delivery Measles during pregnancy is associated with spontaneous abortion and premature delivery. Measles in the offspring of mothers with measles ranges from mild to severe; therefore, it is recommended that infants born to such mothers be passively immunized with immunoglobulins at birth.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Measles during pregnancy is not known to cause congenital abnormalities of the fetus. Option: C. This is incorrect since measles doesn’t cause any congenital abnormalities. Option: D . This Is incorrect since premature delivery is one of the outcomes of measles during pregnancy.

questions.text: A female 9-year child, with a history of 3 days fever, development of maculopapular rash, and vesicular eruptions that originated from behind the ear and then progressed to the trunk, comes to the doctor. On physical examination, a doctor finds that lesions faded on limbs. They are concentrated at the trunk and axilla. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Measles Rashes appear 4 days after fever. They appear first on the face (behind the ear, forehead, along the hairline) and spread downwards. Even Koplik spot in oral mucosa is definitive for measles The rashes are generalized , maculopapular, and reddish (due to Micro hemorrhages). The rash is said to "stain," changing color from red to dark brown before disappearing. It disappears in the next 4–5 days As we go centrifugally, rashes fade out.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Chickenpox Following are the characteristics of the chickenpox rash: Centripetal Seldom affected Axilla affected Rash mostly on flexor surfaces. Superficial unilocular; dew-drop like appearance Rash is pleomorphic, Option: C. Smallpox Features of the rash of smallpox: Centrifugal Palms and soles frequently involved Cl axilla usually free Rash predominant on extensor surfaces and bony prominences. Characteristics of the rash • deep-seated vesicles multilocular and umbilicated. Only one stage of rash may be seen at one time Option: D. Allergy Rash by allergy involves all body parts; the rash stages will be the same all over the body. Also will have other signs of inflammation Vesicular eruptions will not be seen.

questions.text: In measles, Koplik’s spot is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prodromal stage The Koplik’s spots are seen in the prodromal stage of measles .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. The eruptive stage is characterized by maculopapular rashes all over the body Option: C. This is a stage for a period of days after the measles recovery characterized by weight loss. Option: D. This is incorrect since option A is a correct answer.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought by their parents with complaints of fever, coryza, conjunctivitis, diarrhoea, and rashes. They gave a history that rashes began behind the ears and spread rapidly over the face and trunk. On examination, you find that child is febrile with a temperature of 39.6 C and a dusky red macular or maculopapular rash all over the trunk and limbs. You also notice Koplik's spots on the buccal mucosa. Parents are concerned about other children at home getting the disease. What is the communicability of this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: 4 days before the onset of rash to 4 days after

options.label: B
options.text: 1 to 2 days before the appearance of the rash and 4-5 days after that

options.label: C
options.text: 1 to 2 days before to 1 to 2 days after onset of symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: Until the end of catarrhal stage

questions.correct_answer: A. 4 days before the onset of rash to 4 days after
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4 days before the onset of rash to 4 days after The child in question have measles. Option: A. The period of communicability of measles is 4 days before the onset of rash to 4 days after. This is important to prevent infection to other children by isolation of infected child till the maximum period of communicability.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Is the communicable period of chickenpox Option: C. Is the communicable period of influenza Option: D. Is the communicable period of pertussis Period of isolation for some important diseases Chickenpox - Until all the lesions are crusted Measles – from the onset of the catarrhal stage to 4 -5 days after the onset of ras Mumps – Until the swelling subsides Diphtheria – Until 48 hours of antibiotics Hepatitis A – 3 weeks Influenza – 3 days Polio – 2 weeks in adults, 6 weeks in pediatric Tuberculosis - until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy Herpes zoster – 6 days after onset of rash Mumps – Until swelling subsides Pertussis – 4 weeks or until paroxysm ceases

questions.text: Which is the most common gestational period for gestational transmission of rubella?
questions.explanation:

1st trimester The 1st trimester is the most dangerous period for the foetus as the organs develop, i.e., about 85% of infants with abnormalities.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. In the second trimester, detectable defects are found in about 16% of infants. Option: C. Birth defects are uncommon if maternal infection occurs after 20 weeks of gestation. Option: D. Since birth defects are uncommon if maternal infection occurs after 20 weeks of gestation, this option is a wrong statement.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child came to PHC complaining of rashes over his body. The appearance of a rash is shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rubella In a typical case of measles, the clinical features comprise the following: (a) Prodromal: the prodromal symptoms (coryza, sore throat, low-grade fever) herald the onset of viremia. They are generally mild and insignificant and less frequent in children. (b) Lymphadenopathy: in susceptible individuals, the enlargement of the postauricular and posterior cervical lymph nodes appears as early as 7 days before the appearance of the rash. This, however, is not pathognomonic since cases of clinical rubella without enlargement of lymph nodes have been documented. The glands may be enlarged for 10 to 14 days after the rash. (c) Rash: the rash is often the first indication of the disease in children. It appears first on the face, usually within 24 hours of the onset of prodromal symptoms. It is a minute, discrete, pinkish, macular rash and not confluent as the rash of measles. Conjunctivitis may occur. The rash spreads rapidly to the trunk and extremities. It is often no longer apparent on the face.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. measles Macular or maculopapular rash which begins behind the ears and spreads rapidly in a few hours over the face and neck. Extends down the body, taking 2 to 3 days to progress to the lower extremities. The rash may remain discrete, but often it becomes confluent and blotchy. In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear in another 3 or 4 days, signaling the end of the disease. The rash fades in the same order of appearance, leaving a brownish discoloration that may persist for 2 months or more. Option: B. smallpox Distribution of rash: A. Centrifugal B. Palms and soles frequently involved C. Axilla usually free D. Rash predominant on extensor surfaces and bony prominences. Vesicles multilocular and umbilicated Characteristics of the rash deep-seated Only one stage of rash may be seen at one time No area of inflammation is seen around the vesicles. Evolution of rash: Evolution of rash is slow, deliberate, and majestic, passing through definite stages of macule, papule, vesicle, and pustule scabs that begin to form 10-14 days after the rash appears fever subsides with the appearance of the rash. May rise again in the pustular stage (secondary rise of fever). Option c chickenpox Characteristic features of the rash of chickenpox are: Rapid evolution Pleomorphism Symmetrical rash with signs of inflammation Rash to appear first on the trunk

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents to OPD by their parents as the child develops a fever, conjunctivitis, and vomiting. On examination of the child, you notice bluish-white spots with a red base on the buccal mucosa opposite the first and second lower molars. This disease does not show an iceberg phenomenon because of

options.label: A
options.text: This disease does not produce any complications

options.label: B
options.text: This disease cannot be transmitted from one person to another

options.label: D
options.text: There are no carriers of this disease

questions.correct_answer: D. There are no carriers of this disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There are no carriers of this disease The disease described in the question is measles. There are three stages in the natural history of measles - The prodromal stage, eruptive stage, Post measles stage. Koplik's spots are bluish-white spots with a red base smaller than the head of a pin present opposite to the first and second molars found in the prodromal stage 1 or 2 days before the appearance of the They are pathognomonic of measles. Iceberg phenomenon According to this concept, diseases in the community can be compared with an iceberg. Floating tip represents clinical cases Submerged portion represents subclinical cases, carriers, undiagnosed and latent cases. Waterline is the demarcation between apparent and inapparent cases. Diseases showing the iceberg phenomenon are polio, leprosy, non-communicable diseases, mental illnesses, and nutritional deficiencies Diseases not showing the iceberg phenomenon are measles, rabies, tetanus, and Because these do not have carriers. Option: D. is right because measles do not have carriers, and one-time infection provides lifelong immunity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. measles can produce complications like otitis media, pneumonia, and SSPE (Subacute sclerosing pan-encephalitis) is rare but specific for measles. Option: B. Measles can be transmitted via droplet infection and droplet nuclei from 4 days before the onset of the rash to 4 days after. Option: C. There are no animal reservoirs for measles. Man is the obligate host.

questions.text: A G2P1 came with the onset of labor pains to the hospital and delivered a term infant in your hospital. The infant has a low birth weight and appears to have some congenital anomalies. You consult a paediatrician, and while eliciting history, the mother recalls having a fever with rashes in her first trimester of pregnancy. All of the following are included in the classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IUGR Option: D . IUGR is found in congenital rubella syndrome, but it does not form the classical triad of CRS The classical triad of CRS include deafness, cardiac malformations, and cataract. Rubella infection inhibits cell division, which is probably the reason for congenital malformations and LBW. Other defects include glaucoma, retinopathy, microcephalus, cerebral palsy, IUGR, hepatosplenomegaly, and mental and motor retardation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Deafness (SNHL) is a part of the classical triad of CRS Option: B. Cardiac malformations, mainly pulmonary artery stenosis and patent ductus arteriosus, is a classical triad of CRS Option: C. Cataract also forms a part of classical triad of CRS

questions.text: While attending paediatric rounds, senior residents point to a child having fever, coryza, and rashes and ask you to examine the child and comment on the method by which the infection could have been prevented. On examination, you find maculopapular rashes, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in oral mucosa, and answers to the senior resident. Which of the following statement made by you is correct?

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: B. The vaccine strain is Edmonston Zagreb
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The vaccine strain is Edmonston Zagreb Measles vaccine is live attenuated and freeze-dried. The diluent is distilled water and should be used within 4 hours after reconstitution. The vaccine strain commonly used is the Edmonton Zagreb strain.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Measles vaccine 1st dose should be administered at 9 completed months – 12 months. The age can be lowered to 6 months if there is a measles outbreak in the community. 2nd Dose – 16 to 24 months Option: C. Administration of vaccine – 0.5ml, Subcutaneously on right arm Option: D. The vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine not killed.

questions.text: A child with dry fever, exanthema, and peculiar spots on soft palate was advised to go for 2-3 weeks of a period of quarantine. If so, what will be the period of communicability of this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: 4 days before and 5 days after the rash

options.label: B
options.text: 2 days before and 5 days after the rash

options.label: C
options.text: 7 days before and 7 days after the rash

options.label: D
options.text: 14-28 days from the onset of disease

questions.correct_answer: C. 7 days before and 7 days after the rash
questions.explanation:
Solution:

7 days before and 7 days after the rash The dry fever with erythema and peculiar spots in the soft palate suggestive of Forch-Heimer’s spots – the pathognomic of Rubella infection. Even the 2-3 weeks of isolation implies the incubation period of Rubella. Therefore the period of communicability, i.e.; the period of isolation is 1 week before and 1 week after the rash. Hence, the suitable answer is the 7 days before and 7 days after the rash. DISEASE PERIOD OF COMMUNICABILITY Chicken pox 2 days before and 5 days after the rash Measles 4 days before and 5 days after the rash Mumps and Rubella 1 week before and 1 week after the rash Diphtheria 14 to 28 days after the onset of disease

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is having low-grade fever, sore throat, postauricular lymph node enlargement, and rash. On examination, the rashes are minute, discrete, pinkish macular, and nonconfluent. You suspect germal measles in this boy. What is the vaccine strain used to prevent this infection?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RA 27/3 Germal measles is the other name of rubella Option: D. RA 27/3 is the vaccine strain of rubella produced by human diploid fibroblast. It is a live attenuated vaccine administered in a dose of 0.5ml S/C . It is also available in combination with measles and mumps as MMR. It is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. DANISH 1331 is the strain used in the BCG vaccine used primarily to prevent miliary TB and TB affecting CNS in children. It is live attenuated Option: B. Edmonston Zagreb is the strain used in measles vaccin e Option: C . Jeryll Lynn is the mumps vaccine strain Some other important vaccine strains OPV – Sabin type1 and type 3 (bivalent) Japanese encephalitis – SA -14-14-2 Yellow fever – 17D Varicella – OKA Typhoid – Ty21a Swine flu - A7/California/2009

questions.text: A boy studying in 4th standard is brought by his teacher to the hospital as he complained of ear ache and difficulty in opening the mouth and headache. On examination you noticed that child is febrile with parotid swelling on one right side and you diagnosed it as viral infection belonging to Paramyxoviridae family . Which of the following sentences are correct One attack induce lifelong immunity The disease tends to be severe in adults than in children Orchitis may occur There are no subclinical infections Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3 are correct Option: B. is correct because sentence 4) is not correct The child in the question is having mumps infection. 30– 40 percent of mumps infections are clinically non apparent. Sentence 1) One attack either clinical or sub clinical produce lifelong immunity Sentence 2) Mumps most commonly occur in age group of 5 – 9 years. However can occur in adults if there is no previous immunity. The disease tends to be more severe in adults than in children. Sentence 3) Complications of mumps are orchitis, ovaritis, pancreatitis, meningoencephalitis, thyroiditis, neuritis, hepatitis and myocarditis

questions.text: A 7 years old boy developed B/L parotid swelling, pain and stiffness in opening the mouth, right sided ear ache. All of the following can occur as complications of this infection except
questions.explanation:

Acute renal failure Option: D. Acute renal failure is not a complication of mumps infection . Complications of mumps infection are Orchitis , ovaritis, pancreatitis, meningoencephalitis, thyroiditis, neuritis, hepatitis and myocarditis .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . thyroiditis B. orchitis and C. hepatitis can occur as complications of mumps infection.

questions.text: What is the period of quarantine in the given Image of disease?
questions.explanation:

2 – 3 weeks The given Image shows the parotid gland swelling, the typical presentation of Mumps. The period of quarantine is the maximum incubation period, hence, the incubation period of Mumps is 2 – 3 weeks. DISEASES INCUBATION PERIOD Influenza 1-3 days Cholera and Pertussis 2-3 days Diphtheria 2-6 days Polio and Pertussis 1-2 weeks Mumps and Rubella 2-3 weeks Measles 10-14 days Chickenpox 14-16 days Hepatitis A 15-50 days Hepatitis B 45-180 days Hepatitis C 30-150 days

questions.text: A three year old male child comes to PHC with mother. Mother give history of child about sore throat and low grade fever. Physician perform examines the throat and sees the following image:What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Corynebacterium diphtheriae infection Respiratory tract forms of diphtheria consist of pharyngo tonsillar, laryngotracheal, nasal, and combinations thereof. Patients with pharyngo tonsillar diphtheria usually have a sore throat, difficulty in swallowing, and low grade fever at presentation. Examination of the throat may show only mild erythema, localized exudate, or a pseudomembrane. The membrane may be localized or a patch of the posterior pharynx or tonsil, may cover the entire tonsil, or, less frequently, may spread to cover the soft and hard Palates and the posterior portion of the pharynx.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. candidiasis Infection in the mouth is characterized by white discolorations in the tongue, around the mouth, and throat. Irritation may also occur, causing discomfort when swallowing.[32] No respiratory symptoms are generally seen. Option: C. viral pharyngitis Will have symptoms like running nose, throat pain and no membrane formation on tonsils. Option: D. lichen planus Lichen planus will mostly seen in oral mucosa not on the mucosa of pharynx There will be no formation membrane. Will have history of pain in oral mucosa.

questions.text: A 12 year old female child of upper class visits pediatrician with complain of sore throat, mild fever. Pediatrician confirms it as C. diphtheriae infection and prescribes treatment for it. The assistant of the doctor, was confused that, as per literature, c. Diphtheriae is infection of preschool, how this can affect school going children. So what could be the probable reason given by pediatrician?

options.label: A
options.text: Due high socioeconomic status less chance of recurrent subclinical infection, resulting in decrease level of antitoxin in body

options.label: B
options.text: Due to lack of immunization against c. Diphtheriae

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Due high socioeconomic status less chance of recurrent subclinical infection, resulting in decrease level of antitoxin in body
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Due high socioeconomic status less chance of recurrent subclinical infection, resulting in decrease level of antitoxin in body Vaccine given for diphtheriae is not whole organism but is toxoid, hence immunity fades in time. Hence in upper class due to lack of subclinical skin infection, there are chances in infection in school going children.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. due to lack of immunization against c. Diphtheriae. Lack of immunization result in c. Diphtheriae. Infection in preschool age. Option: C. less effective vaccine Efficacy of vaccine is good, as result in formation of antibody, but due lack of subclinical infection immunity antibody fades from body. Option: D. it was a mistake by paediatrician

questions.text: A three year old male child comes to PHC with mother. Mother give history of child about sore throat and low grade fever. Physician perform examines the throat and sees whitish membrane on tonsils which bleeds on peeling off. Medical officer see total 6 such cases in a period of 7 days. At least 2 culture obtained in 24 hours apart from nose and throat are negative As per current guidelines, a case or carrier may be considered non-communicable, when at least 2 cultures properly obtained from nose and throat, 24 hours apart, are negative for diphtheria bacilli.

questions.text: In a survey it was found out that by age of 6-8 years, 75% of children in developing countries have antitoxin against toxin of c. Diphtheriae. What could be the likely reason for it?

Subclinical, recurrent skin infection As immunization for c. diphtheriae, immunity against it fades with time due to absence of whole organism in the vaccine. Hence subclinical infection plays a major role for maintaining level of antitoxin in the body.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. effective immunization programme Immunization in developing country is not 100% w.r.t. Developed countries, still less cases of c. Diphtheriae infection due to more subclinical infection. Option: C. large number of clinical infection If clinical infection increases than incidence of disease in cases

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: No prophylaxis is needed in this case for parents

questions.correct_answer: B. Give prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Give prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin Contacts should have throat swabbed and their immunity status determined Different situations pose different options : (a) where primary immunization or booster dose was received within the previous 2 years, no further action would be needed (b) where primary course or booster dose of diphtheria toxoid was received more than 2 years before, only a booster dose of diphtheria toxoid need be given (c) Close contact should receive prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin.They should be given 1000-2000 units of diphtheria antitoxin and actively immunized against diphtheria.

questions.text: An 18 year old man with recurrent rhinitis visits doctor. He was found to be a carrier of c. diphtheriae. So, which of following method cannot be used to remove carrier state.

options.label: C
options.text: Giving booster dose of diphtheria toxoid

questions.correct_answer: B. 10 day oral course of erythromycin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10 day oral course of erythromycin Carriers are common sources of infection, their ratio is estimated to be 95 carriers for clinical cases. Carriers may be temporary or chronic; Nasal or throat carriers. The nasal carriers are particularly dangerous as source of infection because of frequent shedding diphtheria of the organism into the environment, than do throat carriers. Therefore carriers should be treated with 10 days course of oral erythromycin, which is the most effective drug for the treatment of carriers. Vaccine is not used to remove the carrier state.

questions.text: An 18 year old man with recurrent rhinitis visits doctor. Doctor took nasal swab and reviewed under microscope where he saw Chinese letter appearance. He was found to be a carrier of c. diphtheriae. Why booster dose diphtheria toxoid cannot remove carrier state.

options.label: B
options.text: Being toxoid, does not gives immunity against bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: Due more chances of adverse reactions

questions.correct_answer: B. Being toxoid, does not gives immunity against bacteria
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Being toxoid, does not gives immunity against bacteria To remove bacteria in carrier state immunity cannot be used. In toxoid immunity is against specific toxin produced by bacteria in disease state not in the carrier state. Hence immunity against the toxin is not used As toxin are not formed in the carrier state.

questions.text: A patient comes with acute respiratory illness. He gave history of fever, sore throat, difficulty in swallowing since 5 days. On examination patient is febrile with temperature of 39 degrees centigrade and a pseudo membrane of grayish white color in throat extending over the soft palate was found. What is the schedule, dose and route of vaccine for this disease.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6, 10 and 14 weeks, 0.5ml, IM Option: A. is correct Schedule of diphtheria vaccine 1,2&3 doses are given in combination with other vaccines as pentavalent at 6, 10 & 14 weeks of birth. Pentavalent vaccine can be given maximum till 1year 0.5ml by intramuscular route. Booster dose is given at 16 – 24 months as DPT maximum till 7 years of age --> 0.5ml, IM

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Is wrong because route is not intradermal Option: C. Is the Schedule of MR vaccine Option: D. Is the schedule of BCG vaccine

questions.text: What is the ideal period of quarantine for this disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2-6 days The Image no: 1 shows the bulls neck appearance and Image no: 2 shows the pseudo membrane. Both are the characteristic features of Diphtheria infection. Therefore, the period of quarantine, i.e., the period of incubation is 2-6 days DISEASES INCUBATION PERIOD Influenza 1-3 days Cholera and Pertussis 2-3 days Diphtheria 2-6 days Polio and Pertussis 1-2 weeks Mumps and Rubella 2-3 weeks Measles 10-14 days Chickenpox 14-16 days Hepatitis A 15-50 days Hepatitis B 45-180 days Hepatitis C 30-150 days

questions.text: A 6 years old child is admitted in the pediatric ward for fever, sore throat and runny nose. On examination you noticed grayish white membrane over the tonsil that is also extended over soft palate. The membrane bleeds on attempt to scrape. On microscopic examination gram positive, aerobic bacilli arranged in Chinese letter pattern are seen. What is the type of vaccine used to prevent this infection?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Toxoid The child is having diphtheria infection. Diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid Types of vaccines Live - BCG, MMR, OPV, Yellow fever, Japanese encephalitis killed - IPV, Pertussis Subunit vaccine Recombinant DNA vaccine - Hep Toxoids - Tetanus, Diphtheria Polysaccharide - Meningococcal, Typhoid, Pneumococcal (polysaccharides vaccines are not effective less than 2 years of age, so conjugation with protein carrier is done)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Polysaccharide vaccines are Meningococcal, typhoid and Pneumococcal vaccines Option: B. live attenuated vaccines are BCG, MMR, OPV, JE, YF Option: C. Killed vaccines are IPV, pertussis

questions.text: Mother of 10 week old infant came to the hospital for immunization of her baby. While checking the previous immunization record , you came to know that the child had complications for previous dose of pentavalent and that was identified as due to the DPT . Which of the following reaction after previous dose is not a contraindication of present DPT dose?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Local reactions Option: C. Mild Fever and local reactions are common following DPT immunization and are not a contraindications for next dose Contraindications for DPT vaccination 1) Seriously ill child needing hospital admission. 2) Severe reaction following previous dose such as collapse or shock like state, persistent screaming episode, temperature above 40 deg.C, convulsions, other neurological symptoms and anaphylactic reactions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Collapse B. convulsions and D. persistent screaming episodes are contraindications for subsequent doses.

questions.text: A 1st standard boy is having bursts of rapid, consecutive coughs followed by deep, high pitched inspiration. It is sometimes followed by vomiting . He also have a history of malaise, Coryza, lacrimation , sneezing since 2 weeks. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pertussis infection The given history and clinical features are characteristics of pertussis or whooping cough. It has 3 stages Catarrhal stage : insidious onset, lacrimation sneezing, coryza, anorexia and malaise. This lasts for 10 days Paroxysmal stage : Bursts of rapid, consecutive coughs followed by deep, high pitched inspiration(whoop). It is followed by vomiting. This lasts for 2 - 4weeks. Convalescent stage : lasts for 1 -2 weeks

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Diphtheria is characterized by acute respiratory illness with pseudo membrane in throat. It may be pharyngo tonsillar, laryngotracheal or nasal. Option: B. M easles infection is characterized by acute respiratory illness with Koplik’s spots on oral mucosa and rashes. Option: D. M umps infection is characterized by pain and swelling in either one or both the parotid glands. May also involve the sublingual and submandibular glands.

questions.text: A 3 year old male child, comes to PHC with complain of fever, rapid cough with burst followed by deep high pitched inspiration, increased severness at night. Child was a son of migrant laborer and did not had any history of immunization, was diagnosed as probable case of whooping cough. The child had a sibling of 20 days. So what should be the prophylaxis given to sibling to prevent pertussis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Azithromycin for 10 days Infants and young children should be kept away from cases. Those known to have been in contact with whooping cough may be given prophylactic antibiotic (erythromycin or ampicillin) treatment for 10 days to prevent the infecting bacteria to become established. The best protection that can be given to an infant is to administer a booster dose of dpt/OT to his siblings before he is born As per CDC, for infants less than 1month azithromycin is preferred.

questions.text: A 3 year old male child, comes to PHC with complain of fever, rapid cough with burst followed by deep high pitched inspiration, increased severness at night. Child was a son of migrant labour and did not had any history of immunization. What is most likely organism causing this disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B. Pertussis Three stages of b. pertussis infection: (a) Catarrhal stage: lasting for about 10 days. Characterized by its insidious onset, lacrimation, sneezing and coryza, anorexia and malaise, and a hacking night cough that becomes diurnal. (b) Paroxysmal stage: lasting for 2-4 weeks. Characterized by bursts of rapid, consecutive coughs followed by a deep, high-pitched inspiration (whoop). Usually followed by vomiting. In young infants it may cause cyanosis and apnoea. In adults and adolescents, uncharacteristic, persistent cough may be the only manifestation of the disease (c) Convalescent stage, lasting for 1-2 weeks. The illness generally lasts 6 to 8 weeks.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. c. diphtheriae Respiratory tract forms of diphtheria consist of pharyngo tonsillar, laryngotracheal, nasal, and combinations Patients with pharyngo tonsillar diphtheria usually have a sore throat, difficulty in swallowing, and low grade fever at presentation. Examination of the throat may show only mild erythema, localized exudate, or a pseudomembrane. The membrane may be localized or a patch of the posterior pharynx or tonsil, may cover the entire tonsil, or, less frequently, may spread to cover the soft and hard palates and the posterior portion of the pharynx. In the early stage the pseudo-membrane may be whitish and may wipe off easily. The membrane may extend to become thick, blue- white to grey- black, and adherent. Attempts to remove the membrane result in bleeding. Option: C. S. pyogenes Clinical features of s. pyogenes throat infection are: Throat pain that usually comes on quickly painful swallowing Red and swollen tonsils, sometimes with white patches or streaks of pus Tiny red spots on the area at the back of the roof of the mouth (soft or hard palate) Swollen, tender lymph nodes in your neck Fever Headache Rash Nausea or vomiting, especially in younger children Body aches Option: D. H. Influenza Influenza infection in children produces symptoms like: Runny nose or cold symptoms that last greater than seven to 10 days Complaints of drip in his/her throat from his/her nose Headaches Facial discomfort Bad breath Cough Fever Sore throat Swelling around the eye (tends to be worse in the morning) Epiglottitis

questions.text: A 3 year old male child, comes to PHC with complain of fever, rapid cough with burst followed by deep high pitched inspiration, increased severness at night. Child was a son of migrant laborer and did not had any history of immunization, was diagnosed as probable case of whooping cough. So upto what time period patient should be kept in isolation?

options.label: D
options.text: Until negative fluorescent antibody test against pertussis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

4-5 weeks Whooping cough is most infectious during catarrhal stage. The infective period may be considered to extend from a week after exposure to about 3 weeks after the onset of the paroxysmal stage Catarrhal stage last for about 10 days. Communicability diminishes rapidly after the catarrhal stage. Early diagnosis, isolation and treatment of cases, and disinfection of discharges from nose and throat are the general principles of control of whooping cough. Early diagnosis is possible only by bacteriological examination of nose and throat secretions which may be obtained by naso-pharyngeal swabs. The chances of isolating the organism are < 60 per cent if the material is obtained within 10-14 days from the onset of illness. The value of fluorescent antibody technique has been emphasized in facilitating the rapid diagnosis of pertussis. The patient should be isolated until considered to be non-infectious.

questions.text: On a viva session, the external asked about the features of influenza virus. In which the student answered with 4 features. But, the external pointed out a wrong answer in it. Which is that?

options.label: A

Major epidemics are due to antigenic drift Where the other statements are correct regarding the influenza virus. Features Antigenic shift Antigenic drift Occurs due to Genetic recombination/ reassortment/ rearrangement Point mutations Nature sudden Gradual/insidious May lead to Epidemics/pandemics Sporadic cases

H5N1 it is a highly pathogenic Asian avian influenza A, but difficult to transmit the infection from person to person. Option: C. H2N2 is a subtype of influenza A virus. It is suspected of causing 1889 Russian flu.

questions.text: The government authorities noticed sudden surge of cases of influenza in a community and took all the measures to control its spread to the large population. Which of the following is not correct regarding the measures taken by the government?

options.label: A
options.text: Minimizing the ventilation of pubic buildings

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: A. Minimizing the ventilation of pubic buildings
questions.explanation:

Minimizing the ventilation of pubic buildings There should be a good ventilation in public buildings as it prevents cross infections by removing the exhaled airborne bio – aerosols.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Crowds should be avoided to minimize the spread of infections Option: C. Use of mask and sanitizer during epidemics of airborne infections is good and should be encouraged. Option: D. Isolation of infected patients should be done

questions.text: As an epidemiological investigation officer, you are contacted by a local health department. They inform you that a large number of persons have acquired mild symptoms of influenza despite being vaccinated for the appropriate strain being cultured. You find that the cultured strain is the same as that incorporated into the trivalent vaccine administered throughout the world. You also note that the strain had a high case fatality rate in previous epidemics in China, where most new strains are isolated and identified for vaccine preparations. The most likely explanation for the outbreak noted by the local health department is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antigenic drift Antigenic drift is most likely the cause of changes in the strain that allowed Epidemiology and infection despite adequate vaccination. Partial immunity or mutation to a less-virulent strain (also due to antigenic drift) could be responsible for the less severe symptoms noted in this outbreak. Antigenic drift is a slow and progressive change in the antigenic composition of microorganisms. This alters the immunological responses of individuals and a populations susceptibility to that microorganism.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Vaccine failure would result in influenza cases with high case fatality rates seen previously with this strain. Option: C. Antigenic shift is a sudden change in the molecular structure of a microorganism and produces new strains. This results in little or no acquired immunity to these new strains and is the explanation for new epidemics or pandemics. Option: D. Herd immunity would decrease the rate of infection by decreasing the probability that a susceptible person would come into contact with an infected person. This would not affect the clinical presentation of those infected.

questions.text: An 18 year old boy presents with Fever, cough, cold, generalized body ache since 2 days. Serology was done and diagnosed as patient is suffering from influenza infection. Which of the following drugs cannot be used?
questions.explanation:

Raltegravir Raltegravir is the integrase inhibitor used in anti retroviral therapy

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Oseltamivir is the neuraminidase inhibitor used in influenza infection – 75mg per day for prophylaxis and 75g twice a day for 5 days for therapy Option: B. Zanamavir is neuraminidase inhibitor and is administered by inhaler (10mg dose) twice daily for therapy and once daily for prophylaxis Option: C. Peramivir is also a neuraminidase inhibitor and can be used in influenza

questions.text: In 2009 H1N1 pandemic the government decided to vaccinate all the front line workers with inactivated influenza vaccine and released guidelines about the safety, method of administration and contraindications for inactivated influenza vaccine. options.label: D

All of the above are contraindications. Contraindications of inactivated influenza vaccine People having severe allergy to chicken eggs People with history of severe anaphylactic reactions or other life threatening allergic reactions to any of the constituent or trace reside of the vaccine. People with history of severe reaction to influenza vaccination People who developed Guillain Barre syndrome within 6weeks of getting an influenza vaccine Children < 6 months People who have moderate to severe illness with a fever.

Loss of smell and taste loss of smell and taste is the symptoms of Covid-19 Covid-19 Influenza Incubation period 2-14 days 1-4days Common symptoms Fever Cough Fatigue Shortness of breath Loss of smell Loss of taste Fever Chills Cough Fatigue Body aches and pains Head ache Runny nose Sore throat Less common symptoms Body aches and pains Head ache Runny nose Sore throat Nausea and diarrhoea Nausea and diarrhoea Symptoms onset Gradual Rapid Vaccines medications Vaccines are available Seasonal and swine flu vaccine and antiviral medications available

questions.text: A 4 years old boy is brought by his parents with the complaints of headache, Fever, nausea, photophobia and stiff neck. questions.explanation:
Solution:

Penicilline Option: A. Penicillin is the DOC for treating Meningococcal meningitis but not for prophylaxis . In treating the Meningococcal meningitis, antibiotics should be started in first 2 days of illness. In case of penicillin allergy, ceftriaxone or other third generation cephalosporins should be used.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Rifampicin C. Azithromycin and D. Ciprofloxacin are used for prophylaxis of contacts. Ceftriaxone can also be used. Ideally should be started within 24 hours of identification of index case.

questions.text: A 3 years old child is brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, cough, fast breathing. On examination child is febrile with temperature of 39.6 deg.C respiratory rate of 46/minute with no chest indrawing. You diagnose the child as having pneumonia and give antibiotic and advice mother to give home care. Mother returns to you after 2 days as the symptoms of the child worsened and the child was not able to drink and abnormally sleepy. What is next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask the mother to continue same treatment for 3 more days and send home

options.label: C
options.text: Change the antibiotics and send home

questions.correct_answer: B. Refer urgently to higher center
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Refer urgently to higher center The child has developed danger signs(not able to drink, abnormally sleepy). So referring to higher center for injectable antibiotics is the next best step. General danger signs Not able to drink persistent vomiting convulsions lethargic or unconscious stridor in a calm child severe malnutrition

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. If the child is improving , then finish 5 days of antibiotics Option: C. As the child has worsened, should not be sent back to home. Option: D. If the child is having no improvement but not worsened after 2 weeks, then change antibiotic and refer.

questions.text: A 5 year old child is brought to hospital with fever, cough, cold. On examination, you found that child is febrile but no chest indrawing or fast breathing. How to do manage this child?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Severe pneumonia --> give first dose of antibiotic and refer

questions.correct_answer: A. No pneumonia --> Home care advice
questions.explanation:
Solution:

No pneumonia --> Home care advice Option: A. No pneumonia --> only cough and cold (no fast breathing or chest indrawing) Rx – Home care advice If coughing more than 30 days – refer for assessment Assess and treat ear problems or sore throat if present. Treat fever or wheeze if present.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Pneumonia --> Fast breathing and/or chest indrawing present Criteria for fast breathing -->>/=50 breaths per minute – 2 to 12 months >/= 40 breaths per minute – 12 months to 5 years Rx --> oral antibiotics and home care advice, inform about danger signs. Treat fever or wheezing if present Advice mother to return with child in 2 days for reassessment After 2 days Improving --> continue antibiotics for 5 days Same --> change antibiotic and refer Worsening --> Refer urgently to higher center Option: C. Severe pneumonia --> General danger signs Not able to drink persistent vomiting convulsions lethargic or unconscious stridor in a calm child severe malnutrition Rx – Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center urgently for injectable antibiotics. Option: D. --> There is no very severe pneumonia in recent classification.

questions.text: A researcher is calculating spleen rate in a community to support his epidemiological survey. Which of the following is true about this?

options.label: B
options.text: It measures the average size of the spleen

options.label: C
options.text: It indicates endemicity of malaria in a community

options.label: D
options.text: It is the percentage of children showing malaria parasite in their blood film

questions.correct_answer: C. It indicates endemicity of malaria in a community
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It indicates endemicity of malaria in a community Option: C. I s correct because spleen rate is used for measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community. It is defined as the percentage of children between 2 and 10 years of age showing enlargement of spleen

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Spleen rate is not calculated in adults because, causes other than malaria frequently operate in causing splenic enlargement in them. Option: B. ‘ Average enlarged spleen' is a malariometric index denoting average size of enlarged spleen Option: D. The percentage of children between 2 and 10 years showing malaria parasite in their blood film is PARASITE RATE.

questions.text: You are working as medical officer in a area endemic for malaria. You want to check the operational efficiency of the malaria surveillance programme, which indicator is best suited for this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Annual blood examination rate Option: B. Annual blood examination rate (ABER) ABER = (Number of slides examined / Population) x 100 It is an index of operational efficiency. The aim is to screen 10 percent of the population

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Annual parasite incidence (API) = (Confirmed cases during 1 year / Population under surveillance) x 1000 It measures malaria incidence in the community API >/ = 2 per 1000 population per year have been classified as high risk areas in India Option: C. Slide falciparum rate is the percentage of slides positive for P. falciparum parasite Option: D. Slide positivity rate is the percentage of slides found positive for malaria irrespective of the type of species.

questions.text: According to revised drug policy 2013 which is true?

options.label: A

options.label: B

Primaquine contraindicated in infants and pregnant women According to the revised drug policy 2013, there is no scope of presumptive treatment in malaria control.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a village in Tumkur district of Karnataka. questions.correct_answer: B. Plasmodium Vivax is the cause for 50% cases reported in India
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Plasmodium Vivax is the cause for 50% cases reported in India Option: B. Plasmodium falciparum is the cause for 50% of cases reported in India not P. vivax
